answers.author: Jonathan Lewis
answers.text:
I take every opportunity to talk to school age kids about the profession and local government generally. I have been lucky enough for the past 4 years to go speak to middle school students on career day. After I gave them a general idea about our government and the profession I used a case study approach. I broke them into small groups and had them work through some code enforcement issues. The kids seemed to like and the teachers seemed to love it.

answers.author: Curtis Davis
answers.text:
Having had a joint career in education and city management, I always enjoyed returning to the classroom.  I have presented to grades 4 through 12.  My advice is keep it grade appropriate and relevant.
Most students have no idea what services are provided by city government.  In elementary I alsways started with their trip to school and pointed out that roads, garabge police, safety issues that may have had an impact on that trip.  
When teaching at the high school level, I actually created a class called "Our Town" and had students run for office and re-create the city after a unit on zoning ordinances and allowable use.  They had to present and explain their creation of a new city with proper zoning and type of government.  They were quite creative.Have them problem solve one of your actual issues.
Keep lecturing to a minimum and enjoy .

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Perhaps engage not just by talking: high school students can also be put to work. Undergrad admissions are selective enough that high-achieving students may seek pre-professional internships, not just lifeguard work. 
My home Frederick County, VA high school had two links to local government service. 
1. A service-learning US government class for seniors. Distinct from the AP course, it spent half the year in concentrated classroom work and half the year in a field project. Newspaper story: http://www.winchesterstar.com/articles/printable/406911
2. Gifted Independent Study elective class to arrange unpaid internships for credit. As a junior I worked with the prosecutor's office on research and case prep. Overview video: http://fcpsmedianetwork.org/HSRProject300/P40ALookInside/GIS.html

author: Robert Carty
text: Many of us talk to K-12 students about local government and professional management. When you have time, share your stories about the grades you've talked to, what you talked about, and how you engaged the students' interest. Thanks!
title: Engaging with K-12 Students
